trans-unit.source: Important Information About Signing Key Rollover
trans-unit.target: Important Information About Signing Key Rollover

trans-unit.source: Important Information About Signing Key Rollover in Azure AD
trans-unit.target: Important Information About Signing Key Rollover in Azure AD

trans-unit.source: This topic discusses what you need to know about the public keys that are used in Azure AD to sign security tokens.
trans-unit.target: This topic discusses what you need to know about the public keys that are used in Azure AD to sign security tokens.

trans-unit.source: It is important to note that these keys rollover on a 6 week schedule.
trans-unit.target: It is important to note that these keys rollover on a 6 week schedule.

trans-unit.source: In an emergency, a key could be changed much sooner than 6 weeks.
trans-unit.target: In an emergency, a key could be changed much sooner than 6 weeks.

trans-unit.source: All applications that use Azure AD should be able to programmatically handle the key rollover process.
trans-unit.target: All applications that use Azure AD should be able to programmatically handle the key rollover process.

trans-unit.source: Continue reading to understand how the keys work, and how to update your application to handle key rollover.
trans-unit.target: Continue reading to understand how the keys work, and how to update your application to handle key rollover.

trans-unit.source: Overview of Signing Keys in Azure AD
trans-unit.target: Overview of Signing Keys in Azure AD

trans-unit.source: Azure AD uses public-key cryptography built on industry standards to establish trust between itself and the applications that use it.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD uses public-key cryptography built on industry standards to establish trust between itself and the applications that use it.

trans-unit.source: In practical terms, this works in the following way: Azure AD uses a signing key that consists of a public and private key pair.
trans-unit.target: In practical terms, this works in the following way: Azure AD uses a signing key that consists of a public and private key pair.

trans-unit.source: When a user signs in to an application that uses Azure AD for authentication, Azure AD creates a security token that contains information about the user.
trans-unit.target: When a user signs in to an application that uses Azure AD for authentication, Azure AD creates a security token that contains information about the user.

trans-unit.source: This token is signed by Azure AD using its private key before it is sent back to the application.
trans-unit.target: This token is signed by Azure AD using its private key before it is sent back to the application.

trans-unit.source: To verify that the token is valid and actually originated from Azure AD, the application must validate the token’s signature using the public key exposed by Azure AD that is contained in the tenant’s federation metadata document.
trans-unit.target: To verify that the token is valid and actually originated from Azure AD, the application must validate the token’s signature using the public key exposed by Azure AD that is contained in the tenant’s federation metadata document.

trans-unit.source: This public key – and the signing key from which it derives – is the same one used for all tenants in Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: This public key – and the signing key from which it derives – is the same one used for all tenants in Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: For security purposes, Azure AD’s public key rolls on a 6 week interval.
trans-unit.target: For security purposes, Azure AD’s public key rolls on a 6 week interval.

trans-unit.source: In the case of an emergency, the key could rollover much sooner than 6 weeks.
trans-unit.target: In the case of an emergency, the key could rollover much sooner than 6 weeks.

trans-unit.source: Any application that integrates with Azure AD should be prepared to handle a key rollover event no matter how frequently it may occur.
trans-unit.target: Any application that integrates with Azure AD should be prepared to handle a key rollover event no matter how frequently it may occur.

trans-unit.source: Depending on when you created your application and what authentication library it was built with, your application may or may not have the necessary logic to handle key rollover.
trans-unit.target: Depending on when you created your application and what authentication library it was built with, your application may or may not have the necessary logic to handle key rollover.

trans-unit.source: If it doesn’t, and your application attempts to use an expired public key to verify the signature on a token, the sign-in request will fail.
trans-unit.target: If it doesn’t, and your application attempts to use an expired public key to verify the signature on a token, the sign-in request will fail.

trans-unit.source: Because a key may be rolled at any moment, there is always more than one valid public key available in the federation metadata document.
trans-unit.target: Because a key may be rolled at any moment, there is always more than one valid public key available in the federation metadata document.

trans-unit.source: Your application should be prepared to use any of the keys specified in the document, since one key may be rolled soon, another may be its replacement, and so forth.
trans-unit.target: Your application should be prepared to use any of the keys specified in the document, since one key may be rolled soon, another may be its replacement, and so forth.

trans-unit.source: It is recommended that your application cache these keys in a database or a configuration file to increase the efficiency of communicating with Azure AD during the sign-in process and to quickly validate a token using a different key.
trans-unit.target: It is recommended that your application cache these keys in a database or a configuration file to increase the efficiency of communicating with Azure AD during the sign-in process and to quickly validate a token using a different key.
